awd_titl_txt: CCP Estimation of Continuous-Time Job Search Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will provide new and innovative ways to analyze decisions to accept or decline job offers.  Job search models are widely used in labor economics to address fundamental questions related to labor supply in a changing environment.  The key to these models is that it takes time and effort for individuals to find a job. Even though these models are popular, it is often difficult to know if all  important characteristics of the model can be recovered from data on labor market transitions and accepted wages. This project will develop a new and innovative framework that allows the researcher to learn about these characteristics from labor market data; the models are also considerably much simpler for empirical analysis than previous models. This simpler estimation method will make these models accessible to a broader set of empirical researchers.  The project will then apply the proposed method to a rich longitudinal data set from the Hungarian labor market to analyze job search behavior over the course of the unemployment spell.  The results of this research project will provide better understanding of people’s decisions to accept or not accept job offers and therefore provide guidance into policies to improve the functional of labor markets. It therefore contributes to US economic growth.

This project adapts the conditional choice probability (CCP) estimation method to a continuous-time job search environment. The proposed framework incorporates preference shocks into the search framework, resulting in a tight connection between value functions and conditional choice probabilities. This approach makes it possible to establish constructive identification of all model parameters, which in turn translates into a simple and tractable estimation procedure. This model is applied to a rich longitudinal data set from the Hungarian labor market.  The proposed application will provide new insights on the extent to which the job offer arrival rates as well as the utility of unemployment vary over the course of unemployment. It will also make it possible to evaluate the role played by search effort adjustment in these variations over the course of unemployment. The results of this research project will provide better understanding of people’s decisions to accept or not accept job offers and therefore provide guidance into policies to improve the functional of labor markets and increase economic growth.

por.por_cntn:
This research project bridges two literatures. The first one is the job search literature. Job search models often operate in a continuous time framework. That is, a job offer can arrive at any random point in time. Workers then choose whether to accept the job based on whether the job exceeds their reservation wage. The reservation wage differs depending on whether the individual is unemployed or employed; unemployed individuals are willing to accept lower wages. For employed individual, their reservation wage will depend on their current wage. The rate at which individuals receive job offers also depends on whether the worker is employed or unemployed. For the unemployed, search effort and thus the job offer arrival rate will depend on how close they are to running out of unemployment benefit. Incorporating this feature is rarely done in structural modeling because it is computationally difficult, and entails solving a non-linear second order differential equation within the estimation routine.

 

The second literature is on dynamic discrete choice models. In these models, forward-looking individuals make decisions today recognizing how these decisions will affect the value of their future choices. A key feature of many of these models is that how much the individual will like particular choices in the future is uncertain. This uncertainty actually makes the estimation of the problem easier, and researchers have developed especially fast methods for a large subset of dynamic discrete choice problems. These ?two-step? methods circumvent the need to solve the model in a way that considers all possible futures.

 

We show that, by introducing uncertainty about how much one will like a particular job above and beyond the wage, one can apply the insights from two-step methods from dynamic discrete choice to continuous time job search models.  In doing so, both showing that the structural parameters of the model are point-identified, and estimation of the structural parameters is made much simpler.  Importantly, the identification of the parameters is constructive and, for the non-stationary part of the model, no differential equation needs to be solved.

 

The model we develop is quite general along multiple dimensions. First, it can incorporate heterogeneous offer arrival rates depending on features of the current job, such as occupation or industry. This heterogeneity extends also to allowing for compensating differentials along these same dimensions. Second, duration dependence can be captured not only through the rate at which individuals receive offers out of unemployment, but also through the offered wage distribution.  We apply our methods to Hungarian administrative data where we show the importance of allowing for duration dependence along both of these dimensions. This paper is currently under revision for publication in Review of Economic Studies.

 

The methods used in this work have also been applied to job search models with different occupations, where accepting a job in a particular occupation affects the rate at which job offers from other firms in that occupation arrive, as well as the rate at which job offers arrive from other occupations.  

 

We have presented our work at many seminars and conferences, and one of us has incorporated this work into his PhD class on dynamic discrete choice models.  As a result, graduate students are being trained in how to use these methods which will hopefully lead to future research in this area.
